title: Data Visualization 1
text:
This dataset contains information on artists, including their names, genders, birth years, and places of origin. Here, I created a visualization the top 5 artist birth years to find the years that produced the most artists. The bar chart at the bottom displays the five most common years of birth in the dataset.


library(tidyverse)

artists <- read_csv("artists.csv")

top_birth_years <- artists |>
  filter(!is.na(yearOfBirth)) |>
  group_by(yearOfBirth) |>
  summarize(n = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(n)) |>
  head(5)

top_birth_years

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  yearOfBirth     n
        <dbl> <int>
1        1936    49
2        1930    48
3        1928    45
4        1967    45
5        1938    41



ggplot(top_birth_years, aes(x = reorder(as.factor(yearOfBirth), n), y = n)) +
  geom_col(fill = "steelBlue") +
  labs(
    title = "Top 5 Years of Artist Births",
    x = "Year of Birth",
    y = "Number of Artists"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








The TidyTuesday data can be found at: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/main/data/2021/2021-01-12
This data comes from the Tate Art Museum (original GitHub link): https://github.com/tategallery/collection

title: Data Visualization 2
text:
This analysis uses the TidyTuesday chocolate ratings dataset which contains reviews many different chocolate bars. I focus on the countries of cocoa bean origin to see which regions appear most often in the data. The plot below shows the ten most common bean origins.

library(tidyverse)

chocolate <- read_csv("chocolate.csv")

top_bean_countries <- chocolate |>
  filter(!is.na(country_of_bean_origin)) |>
  count(country_of_bean_origin, sort = TRUE) |>
  head(10)

top_bean_countries

# A tibble: 10 × 2
   country_of_bean_origin     n
   <chr>                  <int>
 1 Venezuela                253
 2 Peru                     244
 3 Dominican Republic       226
 4 Ecuador                  219
 5 Madagascar               177
 6 Blend                    156
 7 Nicaragua                100
 8 Bolivia                   80
 9 Colombia                  79
10 Tanzania                  79



ggplot(top_bean_countries, aes(x = reorder(country_of_bean_origin, n), y = n)) +
  geom_col(fill = "chocolate4") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Countries of Cocoa Bean Origin",
    x = "Country of Bean Origin",
    y = "Number of Reviews"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








The TidyTuesday data can be found at: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/main/data/2022/2022-01-18
This data comes from Flavors of Cacao by way of Georgios and Kelsey. (original link): https://flavorsofcacao.com/chocolate_database.html

title: William Walz
text: Hi, this is for my Data Science class! I’ve made two visualizations of random TidyTuesday datasets for Project 1, and two more visualizations for Project 2.

title: Project 2: Text Analysis
text:
Overview
I analyze the titles of the Federalist Papers to see if some authors used longer or shorter titles.


Show code
library(tidyverse)
library(stringr)
library(readr)

titles <- read_csv("title_author.csv")

head(titles)


# A tibble: 6 × 4
  paper author   disputed title                                                 
  <dbl> <chr>    <chr>    <chr>                                                 
1     1 Hamilton no       FEDERALIST No. I. General Introduction                
2     2 Jay      no       FEDERALIST No. II. Concerning Dangers from Foreign Fo…
3     3 Jay      no       FEDERALIST No. III. The Same Subject Continued (Conce…
4     4 Jay      no       FEDERALIST No. IV. The Same Subject Continued (Concer…
5     5 Jay      no       FEDERALIST No. V. The Same Subject Continued (Concern…
6     6 Hamilton no       FEDERALIST No. VI. Concerning Dangers from Dissension…




Show code
titles_clean <- titles |>
  mutate(
    clean_title = str_replace_all(title, "^FEDERALIST No\\. [IVXLC]+\\.\\s*", ""),
    clean_title = str_replace_all(clean_title, "\\([^)]*\\)", ""),
    clean_title = str_replace_all(clean_title, "[[:punct:]]", ""),
    title_length = str_length(clean_title)
  )

by_author <- titles_clean |>
  group_by(author) |>
  summarise(
    n_papers = n(),
    mean_chars = mean(title_length, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(mean_chars))

by_author


# A tibble: 3 × 3
  author   n_papers mean_chars
  <chr>       <int>      <dbl>
1 Madison        29       59.3
2 Hamilton       51       44.2
3 Jay             5       31.2


This table summarizes the average cleaned title length (in characters) by author. Madison’s titles are longest on average, while Hamilton and Jay tend to use slightly shorter titles. Madison had 29 papers, Hamilton 51, and Jay 5.


Show code
titles_clean_copy <- titles_clean
titles_starting_with_the <- titles_clean |>
  select(
    clean_title, author
  ) |>
  mutate(
    begins_with_the = ifelse(str_detect(clean_title, "^The(?=\\b)"), 1, 0)
  ) |>
  group_by(author
  ) |>
  summarize(avg_use_the = mean(begins_with_the) * 100)

titles_starting_with_the


# A tibble: 3 × 2
  author   avg_use_the
  <chr>          <dbl>
1 Hamilton        80.4
2 Jay             80  
3 Madison         69.0


Here I found titles that began with “The” using str_detect(*). The positive lookahead (?=\b) made sure that the “The” was matched as a whole word at the start.


Show code
ggplot(by_author, aes(x = author, y = mean_chars)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x = "Author",
    y = "Average Number of Characters Per Title",
    title = "Average Federalist Paper Title Length by Author",
    subtitle = "Characters after removing Federalist, prefixes, parentheses"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









This chart visualizes the differences in average title length across authors, and puts into perspective the table from by_author. Madison shows the highest mean character count, suggesting that he may have had a preference for longer or more descriptive titles. Jay has the lowest mean count, with Hamilton in the middle of the two.


Show code
ggplot(titles_starting_with_the, aes(x = author, y = avg_use_the)) +
  geom_col(fill = "darkgreen", width = 0.75) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 100)) +
  labs(
    x = "Author",
    y = "Percent of Titles beginning with 'The'",
    title = "Percent of Titles beginning with 'The' by Author"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









This plot shows the share of each author’s titles that start with “The.” Differences are small, particularly between Hamilton and Jay (with Hamilton having the highest by a very tiny margin), but the pattern displays variation in how authors write their titles.
Data: Nicholas J. Horton, FederalistPapers dataset. CSV used: title_author.csv.
Source: https://github.com/nicholasjhorton/FederalistPapers
